title: How to Tie a Loop Knot

steps.title: Make an overhand knot.
steps.content: Make an overhand knot. Cross the end of the thread back over itself. Leave about 4 inches (10 cm) of thread toward the end of the line. Wrap it around the other side, and then pull the end back towards you through the middle of the loop. Tighten it up until the loop is a bit smaller than a dime. [2] X Expert Source Britt Edelen Boy Scout Expert Interview. 7 February 2020. This knot is also called the non-slip knot. It's a tight knot, and it doesn't snag on weeds when fishing because the tag end of the line faces down towards the hook.

steps.title: Thread the hook on if you're using one.
steps.content: Thread the hook on if you're using one. If you're using the knot for fishing, push the end of the string through the eye hole in the top of the hook. Pull the hook toward the knot you made earlier. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Push the end of the thread back through the loop.
steps.content: Push the end of the thread back through the loop. Keep the hook between the end of the line and the loop. Thread the end of the line back through the loop and up toward the main, longer part of the line. [4] X Research source When choosing where to push the thread through, pick the side that's facing slightly downward toward the end of the thread.

steps.title: Wrap the thread around itself.
steps.content: Wrap the thread around itself. Moving up the line toward the main part of the thread, take the tail end of the line and wrap it up and around the main part of the line 3-5 times. Turn the end back toward the bottom, and slip it through the loop again. [5] X Expert Source Britt Edelen Boy Scout Expert Interview. 7 February 2020. This time, push it through the side of the loop that's facing slightly upward toward the rest of the thread.

steps.title: Tighten and adjust the loop.
steps.content: Tighten and adjust the loop. Pull on the end of the line slightly to tighten it and then add a little bit of water on the main part of the knot so you don't burn the line against itself. Pull on it until the knot tightens up completely, and chop off the end, leaving less than 0.5 inches (1.3 cm). [6] X Expert Source Britt Edelen Boy Scout Expert Interview. 7 February 2020. To adjust the loop, pull on the end of the thread to make the loop smaller. Pull on the main part of the line to make the loop bigger.

steps.title: Create a simple loop by passing the line behind itself.
steps.content: Create a simple loop by passing the line behind itself. It's easier to do this loop on a table the first time. Lay the line out, and bring the end of the thread up toward the main part of the line. Pass it underneath the main line, creating a loop. [7] X Expert Source Britt Edelen Boy Scout Expert Interview. 7 February 2020. You'll need to leave enough room at the end of the line to make another loop, so leave at least 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm).

steps.title: Pass the end of the loop back over the top end of the other loop.
steps.content: Pass the end of the loop back over the top end of the other loop. Pick up the end of the line. Pass it over the main line again, including the top of the loop you just made. Create a second loop by tucking the end underneath the main line. The second loop will overlap the top of the first loop, like scales. [8] X Research source If you want to add a hook, thread it onto the second loop before you pass the end of the line underneath the main line.

steps.title: Bring the end of the line between the 2 loops you've made.
steps.content: Bring the end of the line between the 2 loops you've made. Cross the end over the main line again, but make it go between the edges of the other loops you've made. The end should come out the other side. [9] X Research source Be careful not to stab yourself if you've added a hook to the line.

steps.title: Pull the second loop through the first loop you made.
steps.content: Pull the second loop through the first loop you made. Stick your fingers through the first loop. Grab the edge of the second loop, including the hook. Pull it over the line you just pulled to the other side and out through the large loop. [10] X Research source The second loop becomes the main loop of the knot.

steps.title: Tighten the knot.
steps.content: Tighten the knot. Make sure the hook is where it needs to be. Pull on the end of the line and the loop end until the knot forms. Keep pulling to tighten it up, completing the knot. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the end of the line back up toward itself.
steps.content: Pull the end of the line back up toward itself. You're going to double the line on itself to create this knot. Therefore, tug the end of the line back toward the main part of the line. [12] X Research source Add the hook to the line now, keeping it at the bottom of the loop you just made. Be sure to leave at least 4 to 5 inches (10 to 13 cm) to tie the knot.

steps.title: Make an overhand knot with the doubled line.
steps.content: Make an overhand knot with the doubled line. Keeping the doubled line against itself, wrap the new "end" (which is now a loop) over the line and back around the other side. On the other side, push the end through the circle you've just created and out the other side. Tighten it up slightly. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap the "end" back through the overhand knot again.
steps.content: Wrap the "end" back through the overhand knot again. Take the loop end and wrap it around the back of the overhand knot. Pull it back through the overhand knot a second time. Tighten up the knot. [14] X Research source The loop you've been using as the "end" of the line now becomes the main loop.
